title: Segmentation benchmark
text:
This repository contains code to compare three segmentation pipelines applied to ISIIS images, against a ground-truth segmentation generated by a human operator.
https://github.com/ThelmaPana/segmentation_benchmark
The results of this comparison are published in Frontiers in Marine Science: 10.3389/fmars.2022.870005. The war machine we have developed – based on a CNN detector – generates the best results, but it processes data with the slowness of a tank.

title: Glider + UVP6
text:
This is the code supporting my paper “Temporal evolution of plankton and particles distribution across a mesoscale front during the spring bloom”, currently submitted to Limnology & Oceanography.
The code consists of data extraction and assemblage, a few steps of data processing/cleaning, some nice transect visualisations and finally multivariate analyses.
https://github.com/ThelmaPana/glider_uvp6

title: Detectron2 plankton training
text:
This is the code to train the CNN-based detector Detectron2 on ISIIS images.
https://github.com/ThelmaPana/Detectron2_plankton_training
The trained model is then used in apeep to detect planktonic organisms in ISIIS images. This is part of the work on the segmentation of plankton images published in Frontiers in Marine Science: 10.3389/fmars.2022.870005.

title: weightR
text:
I work out regularly, and to make my little Kermit (see below) legs bigger, I always have to lift more. But how much more?  Well, there are several ways of doing this, but it always involves a number of calculations, taking into account the performance of the last session and the weight of the bar. And that’s not counting the calculation of the weights to be lifted for warm up. In the end, it’s not that complicated, but it can be made easier with Shiny!
https://github.com/ThelmaPana/weightR



Accurate representation of me and my big Kermit legs on my bike.

title: Transcut
text:
This is a little shiny app to cut transects from glider data, based on yo depth and on a map. This process can be easily done with some code but I chose to design an app so that anyone can do it. Just like my other shiny apps, it is probably not the most efficient, but it works!
https://github.com/ThelmaPana/transcut

title: Happy Plants
text:
I have many, many plants (but you can never have enough plants, right?), and knowing when to water each one is not easy. You have to take into account the water and fertiliser requirements of each plant, as well as the season. To make my job easier, I’ve created this app, which gives me a daily list of plants to water. I declare in the app which plants I’ve actually watered (some may only need watering in a day or two), and it updates the database, including the last watering date, so that the next watering date is computed. The same goes for fertiliser.
It’s certainly not coded in the best possible way, but it works, and my plants are happy!
The code is here: https://github.com/ThelmaPana/happy_plants

title: Planktyp
text:
This is the code supporting my paper “Three mesoplanktonic worlds resolved by in situ imaging in the upper 500 m of the global ocean”, currently under review in Global Ecology and Biogeography.
It consists of data extraction, a lot of data processing/cleaning, a few multivariate analyses and nice visualisations.
https://github.com/ThelmaPana/planktyp
The preprint is available here.

title: About me
text:
I am a recent PhD graduate from the Laboratoire d’Océanographie de Villefranche (France). I develop and apply machine learning tools to study large plankton datasets in order to investigate its distribution at various scales.
Overall, I like applying computational tools to solve practical problems, and not only in my professional life. I really enjoy coding, thinking about how to turn a problem around so that it can be solved with numerical tools, and learning new numerical skills!

Outside of the work place, I enjoy a wide range of sporting activities. I mainly ride my road bike (long live bike commuting!), I also regularly do weight training and a little less regularly run. I’ve also recently taken up triathlon, but I have to say that swimming isn’t my strong point, so at least that leaves me plenty of room for improvement! Finally, I’m lucky enough to live in a magnificent region that offers many hiking routes.
I also practiced roller derby for 3 years, first with the Western Australia Roller Derby, in Perth, and then in Nice with the Nice Roller Derby.
Before that, I was a scuba diver for 18 years (I started when I was 7), and I also did some freediving, which I plan to take up again one day.
